3v2.title: Fractional bits: Expected Cost
3v2.text:
Consider the [3tz GalCom] thought experiment, where you regularly have to send large volumes of information through deep space, and every bit of information is very expensive. Imagine that a very important earnings report is coming up for Company X, and you want to transmit instructions to your automated trader in the Vega system the instant that the information becomes available. Let's say that there are 7 different messages you might want to transmit, from -3 (meaning "company X did very poorly") to +3 (meaning "company X did very well"). For simplicity's sake, let's say that you've designed your rating system such that each result seems equally likely.

How many bits do you need to reserve on GalCom to ensure that you can send one of those 11 messages the moment that the earnings report comes out? $\log_2(7)\approx 2.807,$ which implies that two bits won't do — with two bits, you could only single out one message from a set of four. So you have to purchase at least 3 bits. (In general, if you are going to need to send any one of $n$ messages, you need to reserve at least [mathematics_ceiling $\lceil \log_2(n) \rceil$] bits.)

You've bought 3 bits, so there are 8 different signals that you'll be able to send to your trader in the Vega system: 000, 001, 010, 011, 100, 101, 110, and 111. You can program your system on Vega to interpret these as -3, -2, -1, 0, +1, +2, and +3 respectively, and then you have one code — 111 — left over. Is there any way to recover that loss?

Yes. You can program your machine on Vega to recognize both 110 _and_ 111 as +3. Then, if the earnings report for company X comes out as "very good," you get to resell one bit on the GalCom market! Why? Because both 110 and 111 will be interpreted as +3, and you don't care which you send. Therefore, you can choose to send 110 if the next GalCom bit was going to be a 0, and 111 if the next GalCom bit was going to be a 1, and thereby shave one bit off of the next person's message.

![](http://i.imgur.com/mbJ4Apo.png)

_3 bits let you [binary_tree_encoding single out one leaf] in a [binary_tree binary tree] of depth 3. You only have seven messages you want to encode, which means one of the messages gets doubled up — in this case, both 110 and 111 mean +3. Thus, your computer on Vega already knows that the answer is +3 by the time GalCom has transmitted 11, so if the earnings report comes up +3 you can sell your third bit to the highest bidder._

Because you set up your codes such that you thought each outcome was equally likely, your [expectation expected cost] of sending that message is 2.875 bits: 7/8ths of the time you pay for 3 bits, but 1/8th of the time you only pay for 2 bits.

So if you use this method for encoding your message, you pay about 2.875 galcoins on average. This hints at one possible interpretation of fractional bits: $\log_2(7)\approx 2.807$ implies that if you're sending one message from a set of 7, then sometimes you'll have to send 3 bits, but sometimes you'll be able to get away with only 2.

But $\log_2(7) \neq 2.875,$ it's about 2.807. Does that mean that the encoding above isn't maximally efficient?

In short, yes: 2.81 is the _lower bound_ for how many bits it takes to send one message from a set of seven, if you pack a large number of bits as cleverly as possible. To see how we can do better than 2.875, imagine two people who both want to send one message from a set of 7, who team up. Now they need to send one message from a set of 49 (seven possibilities for the first message times seven possibilities for the second). This requires reserving at least $\lceil \log_2(49) \rceil = 6$ bits, thereby purchasing 64 different signals (000000 through 111111). $64 - 49 = 15$ of those signals will have a double meaning, which means that 15/49 of the time, one bit can be resold. Thus, the expected cost to send two messages from two sets of seven is $6 - \frac{15}{49} \approx 5.694$ bits. When the two parties split the costs, they pay only half that ($\approx 2.847$ bits) in expectation — slightly better than the 2.875 they would have paid if they worked alone.

If you pack three 7-messages together, the expected cost comes out to $(9 - \frac{169}{343})\approx 8.507$ bits, for an average cost of $\approx 2.836$ bits per 7-message: slightly closer still to the $2.807$ bound. In the limit, as you pack more and more 7-messages together, $\log_2(7)$ is the smallest average cost you can get. (For more on why, see [trit_in_bits How many bits is a trit?] and the page on [ converting between units of information].)

\[work in progress]
